case_name: Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 71 to 73 of 1950

facts.text: Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 71 to 73 of 1950 filed under Article 136 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Petitions Nos. 71 to 73 of 1950. Petitions under Art. 136 of the Constitution praying for special leave to appeal to the Supreme Court from the orders of the High Court of Judicature at Hydrabad dated 12th, 13th and 14th Dccember, 1949, dismissing the appeals prcferred by the petitioners against orders of the Special Tribunal of Hyderabad companyvicting them of murder and sentencing them to death.

anchor.surface_text: from the orders of the High Court of Judicature at Hydrabad dated 12th, 13th and 14th Dccember, 1949, dismissing the appeals prcferred by the petitioners against orders of the Special Tribunal of Hyderabad companyvicting them of murder and sentencing them to death. The material facts and arguments of the companynsel appear from the judgmcnt.

facts.text: Special Tribunal of Hyderabad convicted petitioners of murder and sentenced them to death

anchor.surface_text: dismissing the appeals prcferred by the petitioners against orders of the Special Tribunal of Hyderabad companyvicting them of murder and sentencing them to death. The material facts and arguments of the companynsel appear from the judgmcnt. N. Pritt  K. B. Asthana, Daniel Latifi, Bhawa Shiv Charan Singh and A.S. R. Chari, with him  for the petition- ers.

facts.text: Special Tribunal judgments dated 9th, 13th and 14th of August 1949

anchor.surface_text: sentenced to death on the 9th, 13th and 14th of August, 1949, by separate judgments. The petitioners appealed from those judgments to the Hyderabad High Court and the High Court,by its judgments dated the 12th, 13th and 14th Decem- ber, 1949, respectively, dismissed the appeals.

facts.text: Accused charged with being members of the Communist Party wedded to policy of overthrowing existing Government at Hyderabad by violence

anchor.surface_text: All the accused were charged with being members of the Communist Party wedded to the policy of overthrowing the existing Government at Hyderabad by violence and establish- ing in its place a companymunist regime.

facts.text: Accused demanded subscriptions towards their communist organization from villagers

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that they demanded subscriptions towards their companymunist organi- zation and some of the villagers who did number meet their demands were abducted on the 21st of September, 1948, and murdered.

facts.text: Some villagers abducted on 21st September 1948 and murdered because they did not meet demands

anchor.surface_text: organization and some of the villagers who did number meet their demands were abducted on the 21st of September, 1948, and murdered. They were charged with various offences including murder before a special tribunal established under the regulations promulgated by the Military Governor under the authority of H.E. H. the Nizam and companyvicted and sentenced to death on the 9th, 13th and 14th of August, 1949, by separate judgments.

facts.text: Petitioners appealed to Hyderabad High Court from tribunal judgments

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners appealed from those judgments to the Hyderabad High Court and the High Court,by its judgments dated the 12th, 13th and 14th Decem- ber, 1949, respectively, dismissed the appeals. The peti- tioners applied to the High Court for a certificate to appeal to the Judicial Committee of the Hyderabad State on the 21st of January, 1950.

facts.text: Petitioners applied to High Court for certificate to appeal to Judicial Committee on 21st January 1950

anchor.surface_text: The peti- tioners applied to the High Court for a certificate to appeal to the Judicial Committee of the Hyderabad State on the 21st of January, 1950. It appears that H.E.H. the Nizam issued a firman on the 23rd of November, 1949, stating that the proposed Constitution of India was suitable for the government of Hyderabad and he accepted it as the Constitu- tion of the Hyderabad State as one of the States of Part B in the First Schedule.

facts.text: H.E.H. the Nizam issued a firman on 23rd November 1949 accepting Constitution of India for Hyderabad as Part B State

anchor.surface_text: It appears that H.E.H. the Nizam issued a firman on the 23rd of November, 1949, stating that the proposed Constitution of India was suitable for the government of Hyderabad and he accepted it as the Constitu- tion of the Hyderabad State as one of the States of Part B in the First Schedule. On the 26th of January, 1950, the Constitution of India became applicable to the Union of India and the Part B States.

facts.text: Constitution of India became applicable to Part B States on 26th January 1950

anchor.surface_text: tion of the Hyderabad State as one of the States of Part B in the First Schedule. On the 26th of January, 1950, the Constitution of India became applicable to the Union of India and the Part B States. the petitions originally filed for a certificate for leave to appeal to the Judicial Com- mittee of the Privy Council of the Hyderabad State were, by leave of the Court, amended, and made into petitions under article 134 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Petitions amended to under Article 134 and dismissed by Division Bench of High Court

anchor.surface_text: the petitions originally filed for a certificate for leave to appeal to the Judicial Com- mittee of the Privy Council of the Hyderabad State were, by leave of the Court, amended, and made into petitions under article 134 of the Constitution of India. A Division Bench of the High Court at Hyderabad companysidered the petitions and dismissed them on the ground that numbersuch petitions lay under article 134 and they also declared that on the merits numbercase was made out for a certificate as asked by the peti- tioners.

facts.text: Petitions for special leave under Article 136 filed in Supreme Court from High Court judgments of December 1949

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners have number filed their petitions to this Court under article 136 of the Constitution of India, for special leave to appeal from the judgments of the High Court dated the 12th, 13th and 14th of December, 1949.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by KANIA C.J. on 14 December 1950

anchor.surface_text: 1950. December 14. The Judgment of the Court was deliv- ered by KANIA C.J.---These are three criminal miscellaneous Kan petitions asking for special leave to appeal to the Supreme Court under article 136 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Petitions for certificate to Privy Council were pending on 25th January 1950

This article was included in the Constitution to enable the Supreme Court to exercise jurisdiction in cases which were not covered by articles 133 and 134, in respect of matters where the Feder- al Court had jurisdiction to entertain appeals etc. from the High Courts under the previously existing law. issues.text: The question for consideration is whether on the facts of the present case the Supreme Court can grant special leave to appeal from a judgment, sentence or order which was passed and made by the Hyderabad High Court before 26th January, 1950

anchor.surface_text: The question for consideration is whether on the facts of the present case the Supreme Court can grant special leave to appeal from a judgment, sentence or order which was passed and made by the Hyderabad High Court before 26th January, 1950. The important fact to be borne in mind is that the Hyderabad courts were not courts within the territory of India when they pronounced their judgments on the 12th, 13th and 14th of December, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out by the Attorney General, appearing on behalf of the State, that if a wide construction is given to article 136 it will not only permit persons who are stated to be under such hardship to apply for leave under article 136 but several other rights will be created. anchor.surface_text: Article 136 of the Constitution of India is in these terms -- 136. (1) Notwithstanding anything in this Chapter, the Supreme Court may, in its discretion, grant special leave to appeal from any judgment, decree, determination, sentence or order in any cause or matter passed or made by any Court or tribunal in the territory of India. (2) The expression territory of India is defined in article 1 ...

arguments.claim: Hyderabad was independent state before 26 Jan 1950; no prior Indian court jurisdiction over its courts; requires specific provision for SC appeal jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: It should be noticed in this case that before the 26th January, 1950, the Government of H.E.H. the Nizam was an independent State in the sense that no court in India or the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in London had any jurisdiction over the decisions of the Hyderabad State Courts.

Such right of appeal to the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council, which previously existed, was transferred to the Federal Court by the appropriate legislation and eventually by article 135 to the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Article 135 provides for matters to which the provisions of articles 133 or 134 do not apply. ... This article was included in the Constitution to enable the Supreme Court to exercise jurisdiction in cases which were not covered by articles 133 and 134, in respect of matters where the Federal Court had jurisdiction to entertain appeals etc. from the High Courts under the previously existing law. This is obviously a provision to vest in the Supreme Court the jurisdiction enjoyed by the Federal Court, under the Abolition of Privy Council Jurisdiction Act, 1949.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to the higher companyrt if article 136 is number companystrued so as to give a right of appeal to the Supreme Court of India. It was pointed out by t

holdings.text: The Supreme Court has no jurisdiction under Article 136 to grant special leave to appeal from judgments of the Hyderabad High Court dated 12th, 13th and 14th December 1949 as those courts were not within the territory of India at the time the judgments were pronounced.

anchor.surface_text: Under the words used in article 136 the -courts which passed judgments or sentence must be courts within the territory of India. The territory of the Government of H.E.H. the Nizam was never the territory of India before the 26th of January, 1950, and therefore the judgment and sentence passed by the High Court of H.E.H. the Nizam on the 12th, lath and 14th December, 1949, cannot be considered as judgments and sentence passed by a court within the territory of India. On that short ground alone it seems that the petitioners contention must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 136 applies prospectively to courts or tribunals in the territory of India as defined in Article 1; Hyderabad was not part of that territory before 26 January 1950; judgments pre-date accession.

holdings.text: No proceedings or appeals respecting the judgments were pending before the Hyderabad Privy Council prior to its abolition under Article 374(1), so nothing transferred to the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts before us, it is clear that as no proceeding or appeal in respect of these judgments of the Hyderabad High Court was pending before the Hyderabad Privy Council before its abolition, nothing got transferred to the Supreme Court by operation of this subclause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 374(1) transfers only pending matters civil; factual determination no such pendency.

holdings.text: Constitutional provisions must be construed according to their plain natural meaning; considerations of hardship have no bearing; hard cases should not make bad law.

anchor.surface_text: Articles of the Constitution have to be construed according to their plain natural meaning and cases of hardship should not be brought to bear on the natural construction. Hard cases should not be permitted to make bad law. In our opinion, this argument of the Attorney-General is sound.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation prevails over policy arguments of hardship or convenience.

holdings.text: Legislation is prima facie prospective unless clearly retrospective; right of appeal is a substantive right that must be specifically conferred by statute and cannot be inferred.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it was then argued by the learned Attorney General that every legislation is primarily prospective and not retrospective. A right of appeal has to be given specifically by a statute and it is not merely a procedural right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption of prospectivity applies; cites Delhi Cloth Mills and Colonial Sugar; no express or implied conferral here.

holdings.text: The language of Article 136 conveys a prospective meaning without need for inserting 'hereafter'; prima facie every legislation is prospective.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended by Mr. Pritt that the interpretation sought to be put by the State on article 136 will require the insertion of the word hereafter in the clause, for which there was no justification. We are unable to accept this contention because, prima facie, every legislation is prospective and even without the use of the word hereafter the language of article 136 conveys the same meaning.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language supports prospective operation consistent with general rule.

holdings.text: Article 135 vests in Supreme Court the jurisdiction previously exercisable by Federal Court under existing law where Articles 133/134 do not apply; such jurisdiction existed for Indian High Courts like Bombay via prior laws but not for Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: Article 135 provides for matters to which the provisions of articles 133 or 134 do not apply. It is there provided that until Parliament by law otherwise provides, the Supreme Court shall also have jurisdiction and powers with respect to any matter to which the provisions of article 133 or 134 do not apply, if jurisdiction and powers in relation to that matter were exercisable by the Federal Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 135 preserves pre-existing Federal Court jurisdiction (e.g., from Abolition Act for pending appeals); no such prior jurisdiction over Hyderabad.

holdings.text: Hyderabad was an independent state before 26 January 1950 such that no Indian court or Privy Council had jurisdiction over its courts; Supreme Court jurisdiction requires specific provision.

anchor.surface_text: It should be noticed in this case that before the 26th January, 1950, the Government of H.E.H. the Nizam was an independent State in the sense that no court in India or the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in London had any jurisdiction over the decisions of the Hyderabad State Courts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical fact precludes implied jurisdiction extension.

edges.explanation: Holding h1 denying jurisdiction under Article 136 addresses issue i1 on whether an application under Article 136 can be made

anchor.surface_text: Under the words used in article 136 the -courts which passed judgments or sentence must be courts within the territory of India. The territory of the Government of H.E.H. the Nizam was never the territory of India before the 26th of January, 1950, and therefore the judgment and sentence passed by the High Court of H.E.H. the Nizam on the 12th, lath and 14th December, 1949, cannot be considered as judgments and sentence passed by a court within the territory of India. On that short ground alone it seems that the petitioners contention must fail.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 on no transfer of proceedings under Article 374(1) supports holding h1 on lack of jurisdiction under Article 136

anchor.surface_text: On the facts before us, it is clear that as no proceeding or appeal in respect of these judgments of the Hyderabad High Court was pending before the Hyderabad Privy Council before its abolition, nothing got transferred to the Supreme Court by operation of this subclause.

In our opinion, therefore as the judgments were pronounced and sentences passed in all these matters before us by the High Court of Hyderabad, which was in the territory of H.E.H. the Nizam and which territory was number the territory of India before the 26th of January, 1950

Articles of the Constitution have to be construed according to their plain natural meaning and cases of hardship should not be brought to bear on the natural construction. Hard cases should not be permitted to make bad law. In our opinion, this argument of the Attorney-General is sound.

edges.explanation: Holding h3 on construing constitutional provisions by plain meaning without hardship considerations addresses issue i2 on whether to grant special leave if jurisdiction exists

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it was then argued by the learned Attorney General that every legislation is primarily prospective and not retrospective. A right of appeal has to be given specifically by a statute and it is not merely a procedural right.

In our opinion, therefore as the judgments were pronounced and sentences passed in all these matters before us by the High Court of Hyderabad, which was in the territory of H.E.H. the Nizam and which territory was number the territory of India before the 26th of January, 1950

edges.explanation: Holding h5 that Article 136 language conveys prospective meaning grounds the interpretation in concept c1 of Article 136 as prospective

anchor.surface_text: It was contended by Mr. Pritt that the interpretation sought to be put by the State on article 136 will require the insertion of the word hereafter in the clause, for which there was no justification. We are unable to accept this contention because, prima facie, every legislation is prospective and even without the use of the word hereafter the language of article 136 conveys the same meaning.

In our opinion, therefore as the judgments were pronounced and sentences passed in all these matters before us by the High Court of Hyderabad, which was in the territory of H.E.H. the Nizam and which territory was number the territory of India before the 26th of January, 1950

Article 135 provides for matters to which the provisions of articles 133 or 134 do not apply. It is there provided that until Parliament by law otherwise provides, the Supreme Court shall also have jurisdiction and powers with respect to any matter to which the provisions of article 133 or 134 do not apply, if jurisdiction and powers in relation to that matter were exercisable by the Federal Court

In our opinion, therefore as the judgments were pronounced and sentences passed in all these matters before us by the High Court of Hyderabad, which was in the territory of H.E.H. the Nizam and which territory was number the territory of India before the 26th of January, 1950
